body_html:
It is possible to restore the weights from a different model (what would happen when you add a normalization_fn) but it won't work well, since the activations would change and what it was learnt before would be useless.

Look at this notebook on how you could assign the variables from a checkpoint, using

slim.assign_from_checkpoint_fn(model_path, var_list, ignore_missing_vars=True)
body_text:
It is possible to restore the weights from a different model (what would happen when you add a normalization_fn) but it won't work well, since the activations would change and what it was learnt before would be useless.
Look at this notebook on how you could assign the variables from a checkpoint, using
slim.assign_from_checkpoint_fn(model_path, var_list, ignore_missing_vars=True)
body:
It is possible to restore the weights from a different model (what would happen when you add a normalization_fn) but it won't work well, since the activations would change and what it was learnt before would be useless.

Look at this [notebook](https://github.com/tensorflow/models/blob/master/slim/slim_walkthrough.ipynb) on how you could assign the variables from a checkpoint, using 

`slim.assign_from_checkpoint_fn(model_path, var_list, ignore_missing_vars=True)`
